awd_titl_txt: Singular solutions in gels:  Cavitation and debodning
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the ongoing research program of the Principal Investigator on modeling, analysis, and simulation of material failure in gels.  Engineering devices generally consist of more than one material.  Their interconnections, as well as the binding of the device to substrates, are susceptible to environmental agents that ultimately cause them to break down, leading to device failure.  It is estimated that the cost of product recall in the medical device industry alone ranges between $2.5 and $5 billion annually, 50% of which is attributed to material failure.  This project will investigate material fracture in polymeric materials, with a main focus on gels.  The mechanism of failure in gels as well as the mathematical methods to address it are very different from those in crystalline materials.  Upon placement of a polymeric material in a fluid-rich environment, such as an implanted medical device in the body, it tends to swell by absorbing water.  Different materials have different swelling ratios, which cause stress to build up at the bonding interfaces and substrates.  Upon reaching the stress threshold of the adhesive, the device may experience debonding.  The research activities will consist of modeling, analysis, and numerical simulation of the phenomena that causes a gel to break apart from its substrate.  There will be a strong and clear connection with laboratory experiments and industrial applications, especially those related to the medical device industry.  Several graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the research.

Understanding material fracture, its initiation and evolution, remains one of the main challenges in materials science.  From the mathematical point of view, the study of debonding requires dealing with singular solutions, in cases when standard mechanical assumptions fail.  This project will develop and apply combined tools from calculus of variations, geometric measure theory, asymptotic analysis, and free boundary problems for partial differential equations to provide a mathematical description of how microdefects present in the material may evolve into cavities that grow and cause the material to detach from a substrate.  The main mathematical difficulty in the study of cavitation is the loss of injectivity of the deformation map that transforms a point in the reference configuration into a cavity surface.  The application of tools from measure theory, such as the distributional determinant, allows validation of the governing equations in the singular frameworks.  The research will provide a unified framework to study cavitation and debonding, and the evolution from the former to the latter.  The project will focus on studying singularities that form in gels, assumed to be mixtures of polymer and fluid.  Swelling of a gel sample attached to a substrate may produce the necessary force for singularities to form.  The analysis of delamination will be based on the conjecture that there are two relevant parameters, geometric and material, able to describe the optimal energy of the body in terms of the length of detachment from the substrate.  One goal is to show that stress concentrations at interfaces correspond to shearing.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal deals with the  study of cavitation, fibrillation and debonding of polymeric materials in the gel state. The research involved experimentally guided modeling, analysis, numerical simulation, with applications to body-implantable medical devices, as well as to the design of new materials for earthquake safety and topics interfacing with biology.  The gel phenomenon is ubiquitous in materials sciences and biology. In connection with the former, environmental moisture causes polymers to become 'gel', where a solvent, for instance, water, mixes with the base material, such as a polymer, giving rise to third material, characterized by negative pressure overload, leading to material damage. 

In connection with the intellectual merit of this proposal, a  key point to understand  gel behavior and, in particular, the phenomena studied in the work of this award is that, a gel, if unrestricted, will simply expand and swell. Indeed, the uniform expansion is the lowest energy state of free gel. If geometric constraints are applied (such as domain confinement), the uniform expansion is restricted, leading to stressconcentration. The boundaries of the domain of a constrained gel are particularly susceptible to stress concentration, that may cause the polymer component of the gel to compress, which, results in solvent expulsion, creating a negative pressure. The latter is the mechanism that produces cavities in gels. These are void singularities occurring in elastic materials as amechanism to release the negative pressure. Overall this pressure is due to the combining effects of geometry and dimensionality of the domain and the specific material properties. In the case that the gel is attached to a substrate by a bonding agent as it occurs in many applications, debonding will occur, if the bonding energy is lower than that needed for thematerial to break. This is the case of body implanted medical devices, such as peacemakers and artificial bone. On the other hand, harnessing the ability of the gels to sustain negative pressure leads to new applications, such as protective earthquake components. Overall, it is worth noticing the close connection between cavitation and debonding, which are different responses to negative pressure, and, both, at the core of this project.

Another component of the research spanning active matter is (a) the development of a gel model, consisting of a binary system of (chromonic) liquid crystal and bacteria. (Due to their elongated shape, bacteria also behave like a liquid crystals that interact with the (LC) solvent. The PI and a graduate studentalso studied several flow and pattern regimes that are formed as a result of the externally supplied (nutrient) energy to the bacteria. The studies were closelyguided by laboratory experiments yielding a very good agreement, in the case of laminar regimes, when turbulence is not yet present in the system. The goal is to unravel a new type of transport mechanism for particles. (b) Cluster formation in chromonic liquid crystal gels, with molecular components as in food dies or two goals: understand the role of of the condensing agents in the formation of domains. These research aspect has recently found new applications to Pharmaceutics, in that it provides criteria for the solubility of the drug, as needed for therapeutic effects, by preventing the phase separation of the (drug) gel components.  

This proposal has produced  three published and (one) accepted journal articles and one recently submitted. One of the articles is in collaboration with an industrial polymer scientist working on body-implantable  medical devices.Also, a graduate student from mathematics (Cora Brown; thesis defence, November 2020) completed her Ph.D dissertation with financial support from this award, and a second graduate student (Ashley Earls; thesis defence, November 2019) received partial support as well. Another student from the departments of Pharmaceutics and Biomedical engineering started his dissertation work under the award, with a focus on experimental work on thin film debonding.  For the last three years, the PI has  been weekly mentoring a research group of young women mathematicians, through the SIAM initiative, Women for the Mathematics of Materials. 

  Overall, this project accomplished the broader impacts aspect required by the National Science Foundation,  in terms of the educational opportunities that it has offered as well as the interdisciplinary and industrial connections of the developed research. The work performed under this award has initiated new lines of research (in particular, expanding the approach of gel modeling to biology, and opening up new directions in materials research, such as in the modeling of material damage in soft matter), established new domestic and international research partnerships, and set new opportunities in STEM mentoring. The PI and former students have   presented talks in many research conferences,  and also participated as   residents  in research institutes, both,  nationally  (Earls at IPAM) and internationally  programs (Brown, Earls and Calderer at the Isaac Newton Institute, Cambridge, UK).  


Last Modified: 04/28/2021
Modified by: Maria-Carme Calderer

The research involved experimentally guided modeling, analysis, numerical simulation, with applications to body-implantable medical devices, as well as to the design of new materials for earthquake safety and topics interfacing with biology. In connection with the former, environmental moisture causes polymers to become 'gel', where a solvent, for instance, water, mixes with the base material, such as a polymer, giving rise to third material, characterized by negative pressure overload, leading to material damage. 

In connection with the intellectual merit of this proposal, a  key point to understand  gel behavior and, in particular, the phenomena studied in the work of this award is that, a gel, if unrestricted, will simply expand and swell. Indeed, the uniform expansion is the lowest energy state of free gel. If geometric constraints are applied (such as domain confinement), the uniform expansion is restricted, leading to stressconcentration. The boundaries of the domain of a constrained gel are particularly susceptible to stress concentration, that may cause the polymer component of the gel to compress, which, results in solvent expulsion, creating a negative pressure. The latter is the mechanism that produces cavities in gels. These are void singularities occurring in elastic materials as amechanism to release the negative pressure. In the case that the gel is attached to a substrate by a bonding agent as it occurs in many applications, debonding will occur, if the bonding energy is lower than that needed for thematerial to break. This is the case of body implanted medical devices, such as peacemakers and artificial bone. On the other hand, harnessing the ability of the gels to sustain negative pressure leads to new applications, such as protective earthquake components. Overall, it is worth noticing the close connection between cavitation and debonding, which are different responses to negative pressure, and, both, at the core of this project.

Another component of the research spanning active matter is (a) the development of a gel model, consisting of a binary system of (chromonic) liquid crystal and bacteria. (Due to their elongated shape, bacteria also behave like a liquid crystals that interact with the (LC) solvent. The PI and a graduate studentalso studied several flow and pattern regimes that are formed as a result of the externally supplied (nutrient) energy to the bacteria. The studies were closelyguided by laboratory experiments yielding a very good agreement, in the case of laminar regimes, when turbulence is not yet present in the system. The goal is to unravel a new type of transport mechanism for particles. (b) Cluster formation in chromonic liquid crystal gels, with molecular components as in food dies or two goals: understand the role of of the condensing agents in the formation of domains. This proposal has produced  three published and (one) accepted journal articles and one recently submitted. Another student from the departments of Pharmaceutics and Biomedical engineering started his dissertation work under the award, with a focus on experimental work on thin film debonding.  For the last three years, the PI has  been weekly mentoring a research group of young women mathematicians, through the SIAM initiative, Women for the Mathematics of Materials. 

  Overall, this project accomplished the broader impacts aspect required by the National Science Foundation,  in terms of the educational opportunities that it has offered as well as the interdisciplinary and industrial connections of the developed research. The work performed under this award has initiated new lines of research (in particular, expanding the approach of gel modeling to biology, and opening up new directions in materials research, such as in the modeling of material damage in soft matter), established new domestic and international research partnerships, and set new opportunities in STEM mentoring. The PI and former students have   presented talks in many research conferences,  and also participated as   residents  in research institutes, both,  nationally  (Earls at IPAM) and internationally  programs (Brown, Earls and Calderer at the Isaac Newton Institute, Cambridge, UK).
